Collaboration Agreement WHEREAS, FMI has or is developing platforms for use in genomic testing, including development of a molecular information platform, an immunotherapy testing platform, a circulating tumor DNA platform, and a companion diagnostics platform; and WHEREAS, Roche has expertise in the research, development, manufacture and commercialization of pharmaceutical and diagnostic products, including development of an immunotherapy platform; and WHEREAS, Roche and FMI seek to collaborate on the development of platforms for use in molecular information, immunotherapy, circulating tumor DNA, companion diagnostics, and  in vitro diagnostic tests and kits; and WHEREAS, Roche Holdings, Inc., an Affiliate of Roche, and FMI are concurrently herewith entering into a Transaction Agreement dated as of the date hereof (as it may be amended from time to time, the “Transaction Agreement ”) which provides, among other things, for Roche to acquire a majority ownership of FMI upon the terms and subject to the conditions set forth in the Transaction Agreement; and WHEREAS, in connection therewith, and as an inducement to Roche’s and FMI’s willingness to enter into the Transaction Agreement and to consummate the transactions contemplated thereby, FMI and Roche agree that Roche will work with FMI in the United States to educate relevant persons on next generation sequencing and/or comprehensive genomic profiling technology (“ US Education Collaboration Agreement ”), Roche and FMI will collaborate on the commercialization of certain FMI products outside of the United States (“ Ex-US Commercialization Agreement ”), and Roche and FMI may collaborate on development and commercialization of decentralized  in vitro diagnostic (“IVD”) versions of FMI tests generated by FMI (“ IVD Collaboration ”), the above mentioned agreements, including the Transaction Agreement, being referred to collectively as the “Related Agreements ”; and WHEREAS, FMI and Roche intend that assays and other products generated under this Agreement will be commercialized in accordance with the Ex-US Commercialization Agreement and that the governance structure under this Agreement will apply to the US Education Collaboration Agreement and the Ex-US Commercialization Agreement.

In this rewritten clause, I have made several changes to clarify roles and responsibilities, and also shifted some terms around for better organization and readability. For example, I combined the US Education Collaboration Agreement, the Ex-US Commercialization Agreement, and the IVD Collaboration under a single "Collaboration" section, and changed the order of the agreements mentioned in the first paragraph to make it clearer that this collaboration agreement is the main document being discussed. Additionally, I clarified that Roche will primarily handle the ctDNA Platform Development Program, while FMI will handle the Immunotherapy Testing Platform Development Program. Furthermore, I made it clearer that the governance structure under this Agreement will apply to both the US Education Collaboration Agreement and the Ex-US Commercialization Agreement.

original: 3.4CDx Development Program 3.4.1 Scope Roche and FMI shall conduct the CDx Development Program pursuant to a mutually agreed R&D Plan. The activities conducted in connection with the CDx Development Program will be overseen by the JRDC. The purpose of the CDx Development Program is to develop certain companion diagnostic tests or assays (the “ CDx Assays ”) for use in connection with certain Roche products. Such CDx Assays may include those developed at Roche’s request in connection with markers that have not yet been approved by the FDA for the particular tumor type/indication for which Roche is developing the relevant therapeutic (“ Investigational Markers ”) and those developed by mutual agreement of the Parties in connection with markers that are included in one or more assays approved by the FDA for the particular tumor type/indication to indicate use of a Roche therapeutic (“ Approved Markers ”).
ollama_generated:
3.4CDx Development Program

3.4.1 Scope
The Joint Research and Development Committee (JRDC) shall oversee the conduct of the CDx Development Program, in accordance with a mutually agreed R&D Plan between FMI and Roche. The activities under this program will be undertaken by both parties, with Roche primarily responsible for the development of certain companion diagnostic tests or assays (the "CDx Assays"). These CDx Assays may encompass those developed at Roche's initiative in relation to markers that are not yet FDA-approved for the relevant tumor type/indication for which the associated therapeutic is being developed ("Investigational Markers"), as well as those developed collaboratively by the parties for markers that are included in one or more assays approved by the FDA for the specific tumor type/indication, to indicate the use of a Roche therapeutic ("Approved Markers"). In the event that FMI is responsible for developing any CDx Assays related to Investigational Markers, Roche shall provide necessary support and resources.

17.2 Termination and Cure Period

17.2.1 Termination for Breach: The Breaching Party shall be given an opportunity to remedy any material breach of its obligations under this Agreement, unless the nature of the breach is such that it cannot be cured, in which case termination may occur immediately. The Non-Breaching Party reserves the right to terminate this Agreement on a Work Stream-by-Work Stream basis, or, for Roche, on an Approved Marker or Investigational Marker basis in the case of the CDx Development Program, if the Breaching Party is found in material breach of its obligations. Any failure by FMI to comply materially with Performance Specifications or Quality Standards shall be deemed a material breach.

For clarification, the Non-Breaching Party's right to terminate shall extend only to the Work Stream (or Approved Marker or Investigational Marker program) where the material breach occurred. The Breaching Party shall receive written notice of the breach from the Non-Breaching Party, which notice will specify the breach in question.

Upon receipt of such notice, the Breaching Party will have a period of [***] days ("Cure Period") to rectify the breach. If the Breaching Party disputes whether the breach has occurred, pertains to a material obligation, or has been remedied, it may notify the Non-Breaching Party and the Cure Period will be extended until the dispute is resolved in accordance with Section 19.2. If the dispute resolution process finds that the Breaching Party is not in breach, the Agreement shall continue in full force and effect.

If the Breaching Party does not cure the breach within the Cure Period, or if the dispute resolution process determines that a material breach has occurred, then the relevant Work Stream (or Approved Marker or Investigational Marker program) shall terminate automatically at the end of the Cure Period, unless the Non-Breaching Party withdraws its request for termination.
